title: Teacher loses £900,000 claim after being battered with sticks for protecting pupil
text:
A judge accepted Oliver Doyle’s beating had left him scarred but said he left his claim too late (Picture: Champion News)

A teacher who was brutally beaten by kids whilst working at a secure children’s home has lost a £900,000 damages claim.

Oliver Doyle, 42, was left traumatised after he was set upon while trying to protect a pupil from three other boys in the gym at Leverton Hall, Essex in 2007.

He initially called for help but the home’s radio system failed, forcing him to put himself between the victim and his attackers, who punched, kicked and hit him with hockey sticks and a bench.

Mr Doyle blames Essex County Council for the radio failure, not giving him counselling and sending him back to work in the unit.

A judge accepted the council’s alleged failings were at least partly to blame for the psychological scarring Doyle has suffered since, but threw his case out because he lodged his claim too late.

Advertisement

Other staff eventually intervened at Leverton, a home for children with social, behavioural and other problems which has since closed, but the savagery continued.

It was locked down for several weeks while the youths broke hatches, smashed furniture, tore up carpets, threw urine at staff and smeared faeces on walls, Central London County Court was told.

Mr Doyle suffered flashbacks when he was moved back to the secure unit of a secure children’s home (Picture: Champion News Service Ltd)

Mr Doyle, of Ilford, continued working there for about a month afterwards before asking to be transferred to an open part of the home.

But he was transferred back to the secure unit four years later and began suffering flashbacks, triggered by the sound of doors clicking shut and the sight of the corridors.

Mr Doyle said: ‘I didn’t feel safe with the management there, I didn’t feel safe with the communications system.

‘It was traumatic being returned back to somewhere where I had been assaulted.’

Mr Doyle said he realised he had post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), giving him a valid claim to damages, when he was formally diagnosed in 2013.

It was only after counselling that he could understand that his psychological problems could be traced back to the 2007 assault.

Leverton Hall, in Brentwood, Essex, has since been shut down (Picture: Champion News Service Ltd.)

But lawyers for the council disputed his claim to have only learnt of his injury in 2013, arguing he had known since the days after the attack that he was suffering.

Advertisement

Advertisement

This would have meant his claim, launched in 2016, had been lodged outside the three-year legal time limit for starting personal injury court cases.

Judge Richard Roberts said he was convinced Mr Doyle was aware of his symptoms earlier than he claimed, and so his case was out of time.

‘I find that…he knew in 2011 that he was suffering from significant psychological injuries – namely anxiety, depression and symptoms of PTSD – which were attributable in whole or in part to the council’s alleged breaches of duty of care in relation to the assault.

‘I find that a reasonable person with Mr Doyle’s knowledge would have considered the injuries sufficiently serious to justify instituting proceedings for damages.’

Mr Doyle has another live damages claim against the council relating to his being sent to work in another secure unit in 2015, shortly before he left his job for good.
description: Oliver Doyle had to throw himself in front of the attackers at secure children's home Leverton Hall, Essex, after a radio system failed.
